Award.AwardTitle: Synchrony in Metapopulations at Multiple Time-Scales: Theory, Experiments and Field Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to understand how and why collections of spatially distinct populations of a species (called metapopulations) display synchronous fluctuations in plant and animal numbers. Synchrony among populations has a serious implication for conservation biology. Synchrony means that metapopulations, on occasion, can be simultaneously rare which enhances the likelihood of extinction. Synchrony results from migration among populations and from environmental variation that affects multiple populations. The relative importance of these two mechanisms remains unknown. The current statistical methods of analyzing synchrony have shortcomings. The degree of synchrony between two population time series is usually measured by a single number, such as a correlation coefficient. However, the strength of synchrony between two time series can vary with the time scale on which it is examined, that is, synchrony may have frequency-specific components. To increase our understanding of metapopulation synchrony, this project will (1) analyze data from large spatio-temporal ecological databases, (2) develop new theory and statistical methods, and (3) conduct new laboratory experiments. The implications for climate change, extinction risks, and the mechanisms that drive synchrony (migration and environmental variation) will be assessed. Long spatially-extensive time series of environmental variables and population numbers will be analyzed to characterize the frequency-specific nature of synchrony. Analytical and numerical analyses of mathematical models will develop theoretical expectations for how frequency-specific environmental synchrony affects population synchrony and probabilities of metapopulation extinction. Experiments with laboratory populations of flour beetles will extend earlier studies in several ways. First, the investigators take a time-scale-specific perspective on both environmental and population synchrony. Second, they examine both equilibrium and chaotic populations. Previous theoretical work has show that these two dynamics respond differently to synchronizing processes. Third, their experiments will involve two sibling species of insects whose population dynamics are controlled by different density-dependent mechanisms: cannibalism of immature life stages and delay of metamorphosis. The former leads to rapid responses to perturbations and increases the tendency for demographic cycles whereas the latter leads to slow responses to perturbations and non-cyclic dynamics. The use of both species will allow an evaluation of the generality of the experimental results. This multidisciplinary approach will enhance our understanding of ecological synchrony and its relevance to society.

This project will have important practical implications for the effects of global climate change on species extinction and will lead to more sophisticated methods for conserving threatened or endangered species whose populations have become fragmented. The research will capitalize on existing ecological databases and will generate and disseminate high quality laboratory data that can be used to further our understanding of the interactions among environmental variation, dispersal, and population dynamics. The mathematical and statistical tools developed will extend the traditional methods for examining synchrony to consider different time scales and will be applicable to data from other fields. The project will also contribute to the interdisciplinary education of undergraduates and graduate students, including underrepresented groups, and will create and distribute instructional materials to facilitate the use of the flour beetle system for training in quantitative ecology at the undergraduate and graduate levels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Geographically fragmented populations connected by dispersal of individuals are called "metapopulations." If extinction occurs in one of the populations in a metapopulation, dispersal from a neighboring population can recolonize the area of extinction and allow for population recovery. However, if all the populations in a metapopulation go extinct simultaneously, the metapopulation (or possibly the entire species) goes extinct. The probability of metapopulation extinction rises if the fluctuations in the populations' numbers are correlated through time (i.e. synchronous). Understanding the factors that determine ecological synchrony and their implications is an important research goal, especially given that humans often fragment habitats and impede dispersal.

The two main mechanisms of ecological synchrony are environmental correlation and dispersal. If the populations in a metapopulation experience similar changes in environmental factors such as temperature and rainfall, this can lead to synchrony of population numbers. The exchange of individuals (dispersal) can also lead to synchrony. The relative importance of these two mechanisms is a topic of much ecological interest.

The measurement of ecological synchrony has relied on variations of the correlation coefficient. Some attribute of the population is measured for two populations of a metapopulation and the correlation is computed. Large positive correlations indicate synchrony; large negative correlations indicate anti-synchrony; correlations near zero indicate asynchrony.

We initiated a new approach to the study of synchrony. We analyzed the correlation of population numbers over different time scales by using cospectra to examine correlation in the frequency domain. Frequency has units of 1/time, so that low frequencies correspond to long time scales and high frequencies correspond to short time scales. A cospectrum measures the strength of the correlation in two time series at different frequencies, much as an audio graphics display measures the strength of a sound signal at different frequency bands. Cospectra can reveal subtleties in synchrony missed by a measure based on total correlation alone. To illustrate, Fig. 1 shows two artificial time series that are dominated by a low frequency component and a high frequency component. Over long time periods (low frequencies), the changes in population numbers in Fig. 1 are positively correlated (synchronous). Over short periods of time (high frequencies), the changes in population numbers are negatively correlated (anti-synchronous). The overall correlation coefficient is zero.

A normalized cospectrum reveals the strength of correlations as a function of frequency. Figure 2 shows the cospectrum for the example of Fig. 1. There is a large positive peak for the synchrony at the low frequencies (long time scale) and a large negative peak for the anti-synchrony at the high frequencies (short time scale). Cospectra for pairs of real population time series measure the correlation strength at time scales distributed continuously over the range of frequencies.

Our goals were (1) to derive new theoretical results to help us better understand synchrony; (2) to conduct new laboratory experiments that test our theoretical predictions, and (3) to analyze data from ecological and environmental databases that extend over large geographical areas and extended periods of time to explore the relationship between the time scales of environmental correlation and synchrony.

We used "filter theory" to derive mathematical results for synchrony. This is the theoretical framework that engineers use to create filters for sound waves, electrical signals, and digital images. Population dynamics and dispersal within the metapopulation "filters" environmental variation into population numbers (Fig. 3). We derived several mathematical results for simple models which we then verified using computer simulations of more complex systems. The simulation results in Fig. 4 show how total synchrony changes in response to population growth rates, rates of dispersal among populations, and the time scales of environmental variation and environmental correlation.

We also conducted laboratory experiments using populations of flour beetles to test our theoretical predictions. We varied rates of dispersal and the time scales for the correlation of habitat size between populations and counted insect numbers biweekly over a period of 80 weeks. We computed the spectra and cospectra of census numbers and compared the results to model predictions from filter theory. The good agreement between our experimental and theoretical results (Fig. 5) validated our theoretical approach.

We analyzed ecological and environmental data to explore how changes in the time scales of environmental variation affects changes in synchrony. The data sets analyzed included freshwater and ocean plankton, aphids, global terrestrial vegetation, and endemic versus invasive species of ground squirrels. We also found that time scales of environmental correlations are becoming longer, perhaps due to climate change, and that these changes impose an increased risk of extinction for fragmented ecological populations (Fig. 6).
